intro: Agalinis reflexidens, commonly known as the narrowleaf false nettle, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and typically grows in moist, open habitats such as prairies and disturbed soils. The plant features slender, opposite leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, and it produces small, tubular flowers that are usually pink or purple in color. It is an annual plant, blooming from late spring to early summer, and relies on insect pollination for reproduction. Its ecological role includes providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a host plant for certain insect species.
